column1: I (50F) am the mom in this situation
column2: and my daughter (28F) has just told me she won’t come to my home anymore
column3: and that my boyfriend of 6 years—call him “Fred” (52M)—is not welcome at her house under any circumstance. We live about an hour apart. I moved to his town about 5 years ago after dating a year; my kids (she and her younger brother) were already out of the house
column4: and he still had two teens (then 18 and 16) at home
column5: so logistically it made sense. When I introduced him back then
column7: after a long history of really bad relationships
column9: steady change. I didn’t know anyone out here and had to start over with a new job
column11: I leaned on him and his family while I built a life.

column1: About a year or so in
column2: we hit a rough patch. He has jealousy issues from past betrayal
column5: made a few comments about my weight that I shut down immediately. None of this is something I’m proud of or think is okay. But we talked
column8: and we started working on it. We’ve done counseling (couples and individual)
column10: and on the day-to-day he’s supportive. He helped me through a surgery
column12: he’s helped my grandkids with bikes and school projects. It hasn’t been perfect
column13: but it hasn’t been the monster picture my daughter is now painting either.

column1: Here’s where I own my part: when I felt low
column2: I vented to my kids. I called crying on bad days. Sometimes you just need your family to listen. But me asking for an ear during an argument got turned into “sound the alarm
column3: rescue mom.” There have been a handful of times in the last few years where I told them I couldn’t do this anymore
column4: then after we calmed down and actually talked
column5: I changed my mind. That’s called trying to work through a relationship. My daughter and son decided that because I didn’t follow their plan to leave on their timeline
column6: they’re done “faking nice.” They organized a whole extraction—talked about setting me up back in their town
column7: had everyone looped in—without even pausing to hear that I wasn’t asking for that right then. When I stayed
column8: they took it as a betrayal.

column1: A few weeks ago it flared again. I vented. Two days later
column3: and we set new ground rules. My daughter’s response was to ban him from her house and refuse to come to mine. She says it’s because she doesn’t want her kids seeing “mean comments to Grandma.” I get that. I also don’t want my grandkids seeing adults freeze out family members
column4: talk about them like they’re trash
column5: or weaponize access to punish choices they don’t like. The couple of times my grandkids overheard tense words
column6: it was addressed and apologized for
column7: and we made a point to keep disagreements private. She keeps telling me she “can’t pretend to be nice
column8: ” but being civil for a few hours so your mom can have a birthday
column10: or a backyard barbecue with her family isn’t pretending—it’s maturity.

column1: She claims this is a boundary
column2: but it isn’t. A boundary is “I won’t tolerate X behavior in my home.” What she’s doing is an ultimatum: “Leave him or lose time with us and the grandkids.” She refuses to visit me in my home under any conditions
column3: even if it’s just me there. She refuses to let him ever step foot in hers
column5: even if there are clear ground rules and consequences. She’s retelling my private low moments to extended family and calling him “garbage
column6: ” then acting shocked that I said she was being immature and mean. She says I’m “modeling a bad relationship” to her kids
column7: while she’s modeling that love is conditional and that you punish people into compliance. That is not healthier.

column1: I’m not asking her to love him. I’m asking for basic respect for my choices and the reality that grown adults sometimes work through hard seasons. He has never laid a hand on me
column3: and when he’s crossed a line verbally
column4: it’s been owned and addressed. We have structure in place. We are doing the work. Cutting him off and isolating me from my own family doesn’t help; it just makes me feel like I have to choose
column5: and I won’t be bullied into that. If she truly wanted to protect her kids without blowing up our family
column6: there were reasonable options: meet in neutral places
column8: spell out zero tolerance for snide comments
column9: step outside with me if tensions rise. She didn’t try any of that. She jumped straight to scorched earth.

column2: I told her that calling me “immature” for staying and branding him as unwelcome forever was uncalled for. I told her she was being mean. Because she is. She took my venting and turned it into a campaign
column3: and now she’s trying to control my life by dangling the grandkids. That’s not a boundary; that’s leverage. If anyone is at fault here
column4: it’s her—for making this an all-or-nothing power play instead of respecting that I’m an adult capable of making my own choices and asking only for basic civility so we can keep this family intact.
